title: Mycenaean culture reaches its high point

note: 750–700 B.C.E. The Greek alphabet is developed. Homer’s poetry is first written down.
title: Struggles among Mediterranean cultures bring about Dark Age in the entire region. Mycenaean palaces are destroyed. 776 B.C.E. As Greek civilization rebounds, the first Olympic games are held in Olympia
Greek colonization means new Greek city-states are formed throughout the Mediterranean and Black Sea areas

container-title: 594 B.C.E. Solon reforms Athenian law and extends power to the lower classes. c. 585–550 B.C.E. The earliest Greek philosophers
note: Thales, Anaximander, and Anaximemes, present new ideas about the universe that have nothing to do with the gods.
title: Sparta enslaves the defeated Messenians, who will serve as agricultural slaves for Sparta until they are freed by Thebes in the fourth century B.C.E. 600 B.C.E. Hoplite infantry becomes common throughout Greece. Sappho writes poetry about the personal experience of love and longing
Cleisthenes puts Athens on clear path to democracy

container-title: 480–479 B.C.E. Greek victories in the second Persian War usher in the Athenian empire and the Classical period of Greek civilization, with enormous achievements in government
title: Though greatly outnumbered, hoplites from Athens and Plataea defeat the army of the Persian Empire at Marathon to win the first Persian War
The Parthenon is built in Athens
The Peloponnesian War is fought between Athens and Sparta and their allies
Athenian philosopher and teacher Socrates is executed

container-title: 331 B.C.E. Alexander founds Alexandria in Egypt. It will become the capital of the farranging Greek-speaking world after his death
note: 323 B.C.E. Alexander dies. Three Hellenistic kingdoms are established by his generals. 146 B.C.E. The Roman Empire conquers Greece and Macedonia.
title: Thebes, under the leadership of Epiminondas, invades Sparta and frees the Messenian helots. (Epiminondas dies in a later Theban victory in 362 B.C.E.) 338 B.C.E. Philip II of Macedon defeats a coalition of Greek forces and establishes the League of Corinth. After Philip’s assassination in 336 B.C.E., his son Alexander the Great conquers the Persian Empire and Egypt
